entry.title: Re: Portugal settlement document number range is not in s...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because the document number and the digital signature reference number are technically two separate number range objects. Even if you manually sync them, the system treats them independently. During reversal, the system consumes the document number range (because a reversal document is created). But the digital signature number range is not consumed, because reversal documents typically don’t trigger a new digital signature. Hence, the NR status of the digital signature remains unchanged. After reversal, the next settlement document pulls the next document number (correctly), but the reference field still points to the unchanged digital signature NR, causing the misalignment.

Check the below areas to fix this

Verify in Basic Functions → Number Range Assignment whether the reference field is explicitly tied to the digital signature NR object. If so, this is standard behavior — the reference field will always follow the digital signature NR, regardless of the settlement NR.

Check if the digital signature number range is intended to be independent. In many implementations, it is not supposed to be identical to the settlement document number. If business requires them to match, you’ll need a custom enhancement or exit to align them.

Confirm whether reversals are supposed to generate a digital signature entry. If not, then the mismatch is expected. If business requires reversals to consume the digital signature NR, you’ll need to adjust the reversal logic (via BAdI or user exit).

entry.title: Re: Specify an internal interval (Message no. NR752) - WB...
entry.content:
Why you see the error is because, when you create/assign a WBS without transferring plan values, the system only needs the WBS number range (which is already configured). When you transfer plan values from the Appropriation Request to the WBS, the system also tries to create Investment Program Position / Budget objects in the background. These objects require internal number ranges to be defined in customizing. If the internal interval is missing, you get NR752.

Check the below areas:

Go to SPRO → Investment Management → Appropriation Requests → Maintain Number Ranges. Ensure that for the appropriation request type you are using, both external and internal intervals are defined. The error means the internal interval is missing.

Check Appropriation Request Type → Number Range Assignment. Make sure the type you are using is linked to a valid number range object with internal interval.

If plan values are being transferred, the system may also try to create budget supplement/return documents. Verify that number ranges for budget documents (IM) are defined in SPRO → Investment Management → Budgeting → Maintain Number Ranges for Budget Documents.

entry.title: Deploying SAP Cloud Connector on AWS Free Tier Using Terraform and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
entry.content:
Setting up the SAP Cloud Connector traditionally involves several manual steps: preparing a virtual machine, installing the required runtime components, configuring system services, and opening the correct network paths. In this guide, the entire process is streamlined by using Terraform and a lightweight SUSE Linux instance on AWS. With a fully automated installer script and a small set of IaC templates, you can deploy a Cloud Connector in just a few minutes. This approach is ideal for sandboxes, learning environments, and rapid prototyping on the AWS Free Tier.

1. Prerequisites

  • AWS account with permissions to create EC2 instances, S3 buckets, and security groups
  • Basic Linux shell usage skills (SSH, simple commands, log inspection)
  • Terraform installed locally
  • SSH client (OpenSSH, PuTTY, etc.)
  • A free-tier compatible SUSE Linux Enterprise Server AMI (x86_64) in your chosen region
  • An existing EC2 key pair (placeholder: <YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME>)
  • An S3 bucket containing the SCC ZIP file, for example:
<YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME>/sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip

Note: Direct downloads of the SCC installer from tools.hana.ondemand.com do not work with wget or curl. These commands will return an HTML page instead of the actual ZIP file, even though the filename looks correct.

file sapcc-2.16.2-linux-x64.zip

If the output shows HTML document instead of Zip archive, the download has been redirected and is unusable. Hosting the installer in your own S3 bucket ensures the Terraform automation can download it reliably.

2. Terraform Configuration

The following main.tf provisions:

  • A SUSE Linux Enterprise Server EC2 instance on AWS Free Tier
  • A security group exposing ports 22 (SSH) and 8443 (SCC UI)
  • A startup script (install-scc.sh) that installs and configures SAP Cloud Connector

Project Directory Structure

A working directory named terraform_scc was created to hold the Terraform configuration and installation script:

terraform_scc/
├── main.tf                 # Terraform infrastructure definition
├── install-scc.sh          # SCC installation and tuning script
├── outputs.tf              # Terraform output definitions (optional)
├── variables.tf            # Variable declarations (optional)
└── README.md               # Optional notes or setup instructions

Only main.tf and install-scc.sh are required. The remaining files are optional but commonly included for structure and clarity.

2.1 main.tf

terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}

provider "aws" {
  region = "us-east-2"
}

resource "aws_security_group" "sap_scc_sg" {
  name        = "sap-scc-sg"
  description = "Allow SCC UI and SSH"
  vpc_id      = "<YOUR_VPC_ID>"

  ingress {
    from_port   = 22
    to_port     = 22
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  ingress {
    from_port   = 8443
    to_port     = 8443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "sap_scc" {
  ami           = "ami-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx"   # SLES x86_64 AMI in your region
  instance_type = "t2.micro"                # Free tier compatible
  key_name      = "<YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME>"

  subnet_id                   = "<YOUR_SUBNET_ID>"
  associate_public_ip_address = true

  vpc_security_group_ids = [
    aws_security_group.sap_scc_sg.id
  ]

  user_data = file("${path.module}/install-scc.sh")

  tags = {
    Name = "SAP-Cloud-Connector-SLES"
  }
}

output "public_ip" {
  value = aws_instance.sap_scc.public_ip
}

2.2 Running Terraform

# Initialize Terraform
terraform init

# Optional: preview infrastructure changes
terraform plan

# Deploy SCC VM and networking
terraform apply -auto-approve

# Retrieve public IP for SCC access
terraform output -raw public_ip

# Destroy when finished
terraform destroy -auto-approve

3. Installation Script (install-scc.sh)

This script installs SAP Cloud Connector on SUSE Linux Enterprise Server, tunes the JVM for t2.micro memory limits, enables the systemd daemon, and waits for SCC to start listening on port 8443.

Note: Replace <YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME> with your own bucket name.

#!/bin/bash
set -euxo pipefail

SCC_VERSION="2.16.2"
SCC_FILE="sapcc-${SCC_VERSION}-linux-x64.zip"

S3_BUCKET="<YOUR_S3_BUCKET_NAME>"
SCC_URL="https://${S3_BUCKET}.s3.amazonaws.com/${SCC_FILE}"

LOG_FILE="/var/log/scc-install.log"

exec > >(tee -a "${LOG_FILE}") 2>&1

echo "=== SAP Cloud Connector install on SLES ==="
echo "Version: ${SCC_VERSION}"
echo "Source:  ${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Installing prerequisites ==="
zypper -n refresh
zypper -n install curl unzip java-11-openjdk-headless || zypper -n install java-17-openjdk-headless

cd /tmp

echo "=== Downloading SCC ==="
curl -L -o "${SCC_FILE}" "${SCC_URL}"

echo "=== Verifying ==="
file "${SCC_FILE}" | grep -qi "Zip" || exit 1

echo "=== Extracting ==="
rm -rf /tmp/scc-installer
mkdir /tmp/scc-installer
unzip -o "${SCC_FILE}" -d /tmp/scc-installer

cd /tmp/scc-installer

RPM=$(ls com.sap.scc-ui-*.rpm | head -n 1)

echo "=== Installing SCC RPM ==="
zypper -n --no-gpg-checks install "./${RPM}"

echo "=== Tuning heap for t2.micro ==="
if [ -f /opt/sap/scc/props.ini ]; then
  cp /opt/sap/scc/props.ini /opt/sap/scc/props.ini.bak || true
  sed -i 's/-Xms1024m/-Xms256m/g; s/-Xmx1024m/-Xmx512m/g; \
          s/-XX:MaxNewSize=512m/-XX:MaxNewSize=256m/g; \
          s/-XX:NewSize=512m/-XX:NewSize=256m/g' /opt/sap/scc/props.ini
fi

echo "=== Starting SCC service ==="
systemctl enable scc_daemon.service
systemctl restart scc_daemon.service

echo "=== Waiting for port 8443 ==="
for i in {1..12}; do
  if ss -tulpn | grep -q 8443; then
    echo "SCC is up"
    break
  fi
  echo "Attempt $i/12: 8443 not listening yet, sleeping 10s..."
  sleep 10
done

echo "=== Done ==="

4. Verifying the Deployment

SSH Access

ssh -i <YOUR_KEY_PAIR_NAME> ec2-user@<public-ip>

Check SCC Status

sudo systemctl status scc_daemon.service
ss -tulpn | grep 8443

5. Accessing the SCC UI

Once the SAP Cloud Connector service has started on your SUSE instance, open the administration UI in your browser.

https://<YOUR_PUBLIC_IP>:8443

You will be redirected to the login page:

The default credentials on first login are:

User: Administrator
Password: manage

After logging in, you will be prompted to set a new password.

6. Connect the SCC to BTP

Once authenticated, the landing screen indicates that no subaccount is currently configured.

Navigate to Connector → Define Subaccount and enter the following details:

  • Region Code (example: us10)
  • Subaccount ID (GUID from BTP Cockpit)
  • Display Name (any label of your choice)
  • Subaccount User (your BTP email)
  • Password (IAS/BTP password)

Save the configuration. The connector will establish a secure tunnel within a few seconds.

7. Successful Connection

Once connected, the overview section will update and display the Connection Status, Subaccount Certificate, and Tunnel ID:

Your Cloud Connector is now fully operational and ready for use. You can proceed with exposing your on-premise resources to SAP BTP via Cloud To On-Premise → Access Control.

8. Observations and Considerations

  • SCC’s default heap settings exceed the memory available on t2.micro instances; tuning is required for reliable startup.
  • In production environments, restrict SSH and SCC UI access to trusted IP ranges.
  • The installation process is ideal for training, PoCs, and labs where lightweight automation is needed.
  • Using Terraform ensures fast, repeatable provisioning and clean teardown.
  • While t2.micro instances and standard gp3 storage sit within AWS’s Free Tier, using SUSE or other licensed AMIs can incur hourly charges under certain circumstances, even on t2.micro. Double-check your AMI selection to avoid unexpected billing.

entry.content:

I am seeking clarification regarding the enablement of the Joule license on multiple SAP SuccessFactors instances (e.g., Test, Dev, and Prod).

From the SAP documentation, I understand that:

- "To set up a Joule Preview tenant, subaccounts must be in the EU10 or EU30 data centers; otherwise, it is not possible to add Joule Preview entitlements."
- "A single Joule subscription can be integrated with multiple SAP products but only with one tenant per product. Therefore, it is not possible to use a single Joule subscription across multiple tenants of the same product."


I would like to know:

Thank you in advance to anyone who can provide guidance or share experiences on this topic.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won’t find them.

And that’s exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can’t and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP — it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I’ll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Integrate Tax Payment Receipt (CFDI) into SuccessFactors employee profile
entry.content:
Hello, thank you to the community for your contributions.

We are currently working successfully with SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Payroll.

We have been processing payroll and issuing electronic invoices with the EDICOM PAC without any issues.

However, in recent days, the need has arisen to integrate the electronically invoiced payslip into the employee profile.

Initially, we considered a solution where the files would be uploaded to the SAP SFTP space and imported into custom objects using templates.

Later, we found this blog post that describes the process of uploading attachments and then linking the attachment to the employee. This works quite well, as we would have the information organized for each employee in their profile, along with the history of electronically invoiced payslips in a custom portlet.

https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/upsert-custom-mdf-attachment-via-odata/ba-p/13411450

However, before deciding how to integrate these receipts, I'd like to know if there's a standard solution that makes this process more transparent and simpler. Both options I mentioned earlier require a middleware to handle all the integration logic.

With this in mind, I'd like to know if there's a pre-developed solution we could use and implement.

A licensing fee is not a concern.

Thank you all for your support.

entry.title: Settings for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer to PS Project and Actual Cost Rollup to PPM Objects
entry.content:
Introduction: In this article, I aim to cover the necessary configuration settings for the financial data flow between Portfolio and Project Management (PPM) and Controlling (CO) objects, such as Work Breakdown Structure elements (WBS). I believe this information will be valuable for all EPPM consultants, particularly those who are beginners looking to learn and advance in the SAP EPPM area.

Settings for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer to PS Project and Actual Cost Rollup to PPM Objects:

I am going to cover the key important settings in configuration for Budget / Planned Cost Transfer from PPM Item to linked PS Project and Actual Cost rollup from PS Project to PPM Item, Initiative and Bucket.

Prerequisites: Settings for Automatic PS Project creation is already in place, you may refer my another article for the same as mentioned below:

For PPM Item to PS Project:

https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-members/configuration-settings-for-automatic-ps-project-creation-from-ppm-item/ba-p/14265007

For PPM Item to Project Management Project and further PS Project from cProject:

https://community.sap.com/t5/product-lifecycle-management-blog-posts-by-members/settings-for-the-automatic-creation-of-cproject-from-a-ppm-item-followed-by/ba-p/14262460

For Financial Planning and Integration in PPM, Financial Category, Group and Views need to be defined, by default SAP has provided these in standard which you may modify or replace with your own Category, Group and Views as per business needs and requirements.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management – Portfolio Management – Global Customizing – Portfolio-Independent Settings – Define Financial and Capacity Categories

Groups under category material:

Below mentioned configuration node is very important in terms of the Views where you actually configure which view need to be updated manually in PPM Item or which need to be updated automatically from PS Project.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management – Portfolio Management - Global Customizing – Portfolio-Independent Settings – Define Financial and Capacity Views

Here, we will mainly focus on Planned Costs and Actual Cost, Planned Costs I am going keep as Manual update in PPM Item and Actual as Integration for PS Project to PPM Item

 

Here, View 5 – Planned Costs we kept as Manual and “Amount Type for Transfer” as “0 Budget Transfer” that means, the Planned Costs updated manually in PPM Item will be transferred as Budget in associated PS Project, if you wish to transfer this as Planned Cost in PS Project instead of Budget, you may select another option "1 Planned Cost Transfer". Actual Cost as “Integration” that means it will be rolled up from PS Project to PPM Item, CO Version need to be updated as 0 to have the current real time value.

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management – Portfolio Management – Global Customizing – Portfolio-Independent Settings – Define Financial and Capacity View for Front-End Configuration

In this configuration node, we map all the views with the respective Financial Categories:

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management – Portfolio Management – Global Customizing – Portfolio-Dependent Settings – Define Financial Capacity Settings for Portfolio Types

In this node, mainly you need to link Financial Categories, Views and Activate Change documents for Financial Planning.

Here, you may add or remove views as per your business needs. NPV indicator needs to be set if current view type to be included when system calculates Net Present Value.

Mapping of Financial Views to Cost Elements

Configuration Node: SAP Portfolio and Project Management – Portfolio Management – Base System Interfaces – Financial Planning Settings – Define Financial Planning Settings

Note: This configuration needs to be done in the respective client such as Test or Production by opening the system.

Mapping of Cost Element is important for financial data flow and is applicable only for Integration scenario, since in this article we are mainly focusing on Manual Planned cost update and Integration of Actual cost, we will see the configuration settings maintained for Actual Cost.

Maintain the logical system, Controlling Area and Value Type 04 for Actual Cost.

Maintain the Cost Element group or Cost Element for each type of Views.

Note: Please be cautious while maintaining cost elements within the group. If a specific cost element appears in multiple cost element groups say for example in two groups and, for example, an actual cost of INR 10,000 is posted against that cost element, the PPM item will reflect an actual cost of INR 20,000 due to the duplication of the cost element across two different groups.

Maintain the CO version 0.

Let’s test the scenario:

Initiative FDTI01 created:

Item FDT-001 created under Initiative FDTI01

Manual Financial Planning done in Item as Planned Cost:

PS Project FDT-001 created automatically under Item:

We can see the Project in Project Builder too:

Currently there is no Budget in the PS Project.

Let’s transfer the Budget from PPM Item to PS Project:

Click on “Transfer to Project System” from Financial Planning page:

Select the line, select “Transfer” check box and click on “OK”, you should get the success message as shown below:

Now, let’s check in the PS Project:

We can see the status BUDG is updated, that means Project is Budgeted now, lets see in the Budget Display transaction:

Transaction Code: CJ31

Now we will post the actual Cost on WBS Element, to post the actual cost on WBS Element, the status of WBS must be Released.

Posted 10000 cost on WBS FDT-001 with Cost Element 51100000:

Now, let’s transfer the cost to PPM Item from PS Project:

Execute the Program /RPM/FICO_INT_PLANNING in transaction SE38 or SA38

Uncheck Test Mode checkbox, select radio button “Integr.,Planning and Rollup” and update Destination as NONE by manually typing into the field.

Enter the Item ID and Cost Version as 0 and execute.

You will get the messages as shown below:

Now let’s check in the PPM Item and Initiative:

We can see the Actual Cost is updated automatically in Financial Planning page of Item:

Here the Cost are visible under Group Machines because the Cost Element used for actual cost posting is being maintained in the Cost Element Group assigned to Financial Group Machines.

In Initiative also Actual Cost Rolled up:

Conclusion: By reading this article and applying the settings in the system, you will be able to configure the essential settings for the financial data flow between PPM objects and CO objects, as well as in the reverse direction.

SAP Portfolio and Project Management SAP Portfolio and Project Management for SAP S/4HANA PLM Project System (PS)

entry.title: TMS on SAP Integration Suite for API proxy transports in SAP API Management
entry.content:
Purpose

Moving API proxies between different tenants can be a critical step in your development lifecycle. This article provides a clear, step-by-step guide on how to successfully set up the Transport Management System (TMS) to handle API proxy transports, building on the assumption that you already have TMS configured for your Integrations. 

Prerequisites
Before beginning the setup, ensure the following entitlement is available in both your source (e.g., Development) and destination (e.g., Production) subaccounts:

  • API Management, API portal

Process
Step:1: Create a service instance for the API Management, API portal entitlement using the apiportal-apiaccess plan. This needs to be done in both your source and destination subaccounts

 

Step:2: For the instances created in Step 1, generate a service key in both the source and destination subaccounts. Crucially, ensure you copy and securely store both service keys, as they contain the credentials and URLs required for the following steps.

Step:3: In the Connectivity section of the Cockpit for your source subaccount, create a new Destination (From Scratch). This destination will allow your source environment to connect and push transports to the destination environment. The details that is used in configuring this destination is from the service key details of destination environment (Production in my case)

 

ParametersValues
NameAPIManagement
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
TypeHTTP
Client IDFrom Destination JSON Key File
Client SecretFrom Destination JSON Key File
Token Service URLFrom Destination JSON key file
URL{{ URL from Destination JSON key File}}/api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport
Token Service URL TypeDedicated

Step:4: Once the destination configuration is complete, you should be able to initiate the transport of API proxies (and API Providers) from your source tenant. A new Transport Request (TR) will be generated and visible in your Cloud Transport Management System.

You should be finding this TR in your Transport Request of Transport Management System.

Problems faced

If any of the below errors are encountered when initiating the transport, check the destination configuration in source subaccount / tenant (Step:3). All the above errors are due to incorrect destination configuration. Check if you have the correct destination name, correct URL in destination configured (destination service key URL with path /api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport), correct credentials (destination service key credential)



Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Destination configuration error in APIManagement . Bad credentials sap apim
Transport request has failed as the destination APIManagement is not correctly configured. Details: Validation failed as destination APIManagement not configured with correct URL

If the below error is encountered, then the integration artifact that this API represents / linked is not actually present in destination tenant or subaccount. First transport the corresponding integration artifacts first then transport the API artifact.

The artifact you're attempting to transport could not be found or has encountered an error. Please verify that the artifact exists and try again. If the problem continues, contact SAP Support for assistance

Result

If you have all the pre-requisite complete along with the above steps, we should readily be able to do the API Proxy transports, API Provider transports from source subaccounts to destination subaccounts. Once you click transport from the source, it should create a transport ID and a transport request that can be seen in Cloud TMS with the API details.

entry.title: Re: Priority based production planning, planned orders fr...
entry.content:
Hello @Jakobstrom 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, the public cloud allows you to give sales orders higher priority than your forecast demand. Activating aATP is exactly what you need to achieve that. I recommend you ensure that you have configured your Demand Priorities in aATP (Sales Orders higher than Forecasts). You can optionally use Supply Protection to reserve inventory for Sales Orders. You can use aATP Confirmation Strategy & Backorder Processing to ensure sales Orders receive supply first. This will ensure production and supply planning always prioritises confirmed customer orders over forecast-based or internal demand.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Determination of the Order Priority

Check out this Blog: Advanced Available - to - Promise (aATP in S/4HANA) version 2023

Should your customer require their production to react faster to ensure manufacturing orders are released earlier for sales orders, as a workaround, you can suggest using Demand-Driven Replenishment buffer priorities. This will ensure sales orders increase buffer penetration, which increases priority in the replenishment list, which triggers earlier procurement or production.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Specify an internal interval (Message no. NR752) - WB...
entry.content: What you should do is create an internal number range interval in the same number range object. Add a new interval (e.g. “02”) that won’t overlap with your external interval. Internal indicator (do not tick “External”). Assign this internal interval to your appropriation request type. In Appropriation Request Type → Number Range Assignment, make sure the type points to the internal interval you just created.

entry.title: Re: Query on Replenishment strategy in storage type
entry.content: The “New Quantity at WT Creation” setting in SAP EWM replenishment ensures that the system recalculates the replenishment quantity at the moment the warehouse task (WT) is created, rather than using the quantity determined earlier during replenishment planning. You enable this when you want the replenishment to reflect the most up‑to‑date stock situation in the storage type/bin, typically in dynamic or fast‑moving warehouse environments where stock levels change rapidly.

entry.title: Onboarding to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition for SAP BTP Subaccount
entry.content:
Step 1: Prerequisites

  1. Open your Identity Authentication admin environment.

    1. Open your SAP BTP Subaccount 
    2. Click on Trust Configuration under security tab
    3. Select Custom Identity Provider for Applications
    4. In the Identity Provider click on Administrator Console
  2. Choose the User Groups tile.

  3. Click + Add and create the following groups:

Note: The Name and Display Name must be identical. They must match exactly as listed below to align with the Identity Provisioning transformation code. If you modify any name, update the transformation logic accordingly.

  • Workzone_Admin

  • Workzone_Area_Admin

  • Workzone_Support_Admin

  • Workzone_Page_Content_Admin

  • Workzone_End_User

  • Workzone_User_Type_public

       4. Navigate to User Management.

       5. Assign yourself to the Workzone_Admin group.

Step 2: Run the Booster

  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, open your Global Account.

  2. From the left-side menu, select Boosters.

  3. Locate Get Started with SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition and click Start.

Step 3: Post-Booster Configuration

Connect Your Subaccount to Identity Provisioning

Prerequisites:

  • The integration with the Identity Provisioning service supports only one active Identity Authentication tenant. Before you start the configuration, open the cockpit, Security  Trust Configuration, and verify that you have only one active Identity Authentication trust configuration in the list. The default IdP, sap.default, is not relevant to the flow and can be ignored for this requirement. After the connection is formed, you can configure additional active IdPs.

  • If you already have an active Identity Authentication tenant, you are required to reconnect it to the Identity Provisioning service after you've modified it.

Connector Setup for User & Group Provisioning:

Note: This step is required only if you don't already have an active tenant with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition connector configured for your subaccount.

  1. Open the Site Manager:

    • In BTP cockpit, navigate to Services → Instances and Subscriptions.

    • Open the subscription for SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

  2. From the left menu, go to Settings → Identity Provisioning.

  3. Click Connect.

Step 4: Run the Configurator

  1. Access the Site Manager as follows: In the SAP BTP cockpit, Services  Instances and Subscriptions, click on the subscription to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition in the Subscriptions table to access the application.
  2. Open the Configurator screen from the left-side menu.

4.1 Create a Destination to SAP SuccessFactors (Optional)

The step Create a Destination to SAP SuccessFactors is optional and can be skipped if not required.

4.2 Set Up Environment

In this step, select the domain type - Default and then click Trigger Setup to complete the  configuration steps required for the setup of your tenant.

4.3 Configure Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning

In this step, you'll need to manually configure Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning to enable user authentication and user provisioning.

4.3.1 : Create an app in Identity Authentication

 

  1. Download the metadata(This will be used in step 4)
  2. Open the administration console for SAP Cloud Identity Services. To do so, in SAP BTP cockpit, go to Security -> Trust Configuration, click the link pointing to your active Identity Authentication and add /admin to the URL.
  3. Go to Applications & Resources -> Applications and click +Add to add a new application from type SAP BTP Solution. Provide a meaningful name such as SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Select the protocol type SAML 2.0.
  4. Open the SAML 2.0 Configuration editor of the application you've created, and upload the service provider metadata file that you’ve downloaded from the configurator. Save your changes.
  5. Open the Subject Name Identifier editor of the application, and change the basic configuration attribute from User ID to Global User ID.

4.3.2 Set Identity Authentication as a source system

  1. In the administration console for SAP Cloud Identity Services, go to the Administrators tile and create a technical user (of type System)
  2. Client ID will be automatically generated
  3. Under the Secrets click on Add button give a meaningful description and click Save. 

Note: A secret will be generated, copy this and save it as won't be visible again

 


  • Make sure Manage Users and Manage Groups authorization roles are enabled for the technical user. This way, you can create, edit and delete users and groups in the Identity Authentication user store.
  • Go to Admin Console -> Identity  Provisioning -> select source system -> Click on Add -> Give a name to a source system and select type Identity Authentication and save it.
  • Go to Properties -> and add properties as mentioned below:

Mandatory Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

Type

Enter: HTTP

URL

<Identity Provider URL from prerequisites Step 1>

ProxyType

Enter: Internet

The Identity Authentication service is a cloud solution and is outside of your company on-premise infrastructure.

Authentication

Enter your authentication method:

  • BasicAuthentication

User

<Client ID from Step 4.3.2 - (2)>

Password

<Secret from Step 4.3.2 - (3)>

Optional Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

  • ias.<property_name>
  • scim.<property_name>

When using SCIM API version 2, property names start with ias prefix, for example: ias.user.unique.attribute.

When using SCIM API version 1, property names start with scim prefix, for example: scim.user.unique.attribute.

For more information, see List of Properties. Use the main search or filter properties by Name or System Type columns.

ias.user.filter

When specified, only those users matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: name.familyName eq "Smith" and addresses.country eq "US"

This filter will read only users whose name is "Smith" and are living in the United States.

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: User Search

ias.group.filter

When specified, only those groups matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: displayName eq "ProjectTeam1"

This filter will read only groups, whose display name is "ProjectTeam1".

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: Group Search

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts

Predefined value: 2

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts.interval

Predefined value: 60

4.3.3 Set SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition as a target system using the following parameters

These parameters are already provided in the configurator tab in the site manager copy all these values mentioned in this step and add it in the target system.

Go to Admin Console -> Identity  Provisioning -> select target system -> Click on Add ->

  • In Details tab give a name to a target system and Type should be SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.
  • Go to Properties tab and maintain below mentioned properties and Save it.

 

Mandatory Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

Type

Enter: HTTP

URL

From the above screenshot Integration url should be added here

ProxyType

Enter: Internet

Authentication

  • BasicAuthentication

User

Provide the value OAuth Client Key mentioned in the above screenshot

Password

Provide the value OAuth Client Secret mentioned in the above screenshot

 

 

Optional Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

  • ias.<property_name>
  • scim.<property_name>

When using SCIM API version 2, property names start with ias prefix, for example: ias.user.unique.attribute.

When using SCIM API version 1, property names start with scim prefix, for example: scim.user.unique.attribute.

For more information, see List of Properties. Use the main search or filter properties by Name or System Type columns.

ias.user.filter

When specified, only those users matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: name.familyName eq "Smith" and addresses.country eq "US"

This filter will read only users whose name is "Smith" and are living in the United States.

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: User Search

ias.group.filter

When specified, only those groups matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: displayName eq "ProjectTeam1"

This filter will read only groups, whose display name is "ProjectTeam1".

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: Group Search

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts

Predefined value: 2

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts.interval

Predefined value: 60

 

4.4 Configure and Run Provisioning Job

  1. Once both Source System and Target System is configured follow below steps to Run Provisioning Job.
  2. Go to Source System already created in the step 4.3.2.
  3. Go to the Jobs tab and Run Read Job.

       4. Go to Identity Provisioning -> Provisioning Logs to verify the job logs, which should display a successful status.

As you complete each of these steps keep ticking the checkboxes and then last step would be to launch the Build Workzone.

 

Reference Documents:
https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-advanced-edition/sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition/prerequisites?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition?locale=en-US

entry.title: Re: No prices could be determined for object KLA000DOMI L...
entry.content:
Good day @AngelT 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, when you use routing in public cloud and the system cannot find matching activity prices for the work center or activity type, it often delivers that error message.

I recommend you check if:

  1. Your work center has a cost center and formular for your activity calculation.
  2. You have assigned your activity type to that cost center.
  3. Make sure you confirm that your activity price is maintained in Manage Cost Rates-Plan for the correct ledger or year.
  4. Make sure your UOM match between routing and activity price.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Cost Center Activity Type, Cost Allocation to Cost Centers, Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Planning, Linking of Cost Centers and Business Processes

From your screenshot I can see that your routing uses MIN, while you have maintained your activity price in H. This prevents the system from determining a valid rate. Ensure to align them and it should resolve the issue.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to connect SAP Solution Manager with Third party...
entry.content:
SAP Solution Manager can be connected to external service desk tools via the Webservice API, as per KBA 2556872. The KBA directs you to the Webservice API technical guide, as well as some additional documentation. The steps in the Webservice API technical guide will guide you to complete the integration fully.

If you wish for the external service desk content to be automatically synched with the SAP Solution Manager ITSM Incidents, KBA 2936030 will help you to achieve this by setting flag "Keep in sync" for the system in ICTCONF.

<xsd:schema xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"

entry.title: How to sort a Dynamic Table in Adobe Forms using Form-Level Scripting (JavaScript/FormCalc)
entry.content:
Hello Everybody, 

I have an Adobe Form requirement to sort a dynamic data table row printing on the form based on the Material field. Currently, this data is populating without any sorting as it is fetched from the Form Provider Gateway Service. 

There is no scope to do this sorting in the backend using any enhancements. The only option is to sort the data at Adobe level using scripting.

I have tried scripting at the Event 'Form: Ready' for the data row  (Row1) of my Table and referred to blogs but this script isn't working. Below is the hierarchy of my form layout and the current script I am trying: 

 

FormCalc script I am trying: 

var tbl = "$._Row1" // Table row
var i = 0 // Source row
var j = 0 // Compared row
var tblLength = xfa.resolveNode( tbl ).all.length // Number of rows
var source // Source concatenated fields to compare
var destination // Compare to concatenated fields
// *** Loop from the first row
for i = 0 upto tblLength - 1 do
  // *** Compare with the subsequence rows
  for j = i + 1 upto tblLength -1 do
    source       = xfa.resolveNode( tbl )[ i ].Itm_no    // Concatenate fields source to compare
    destination  = xfa.resolveNode( tbl )[ j ].Itm_no    // Concatenate fields to compare with
    if ( source > destination ) then
      xfa.resolveNode( tbl).instanceManager.moveInstance( j, i )
    endif
  endfor // j
endfor // i

 

JavaScript Code I tried: 

(function(){  
    var rows = this.resolveNodes("Row1[*]");  
    var rowCount = rows.length;       
    if (rowCount <= 1) return;       
    // Bubble sort    
    for (var i = 0; i < rowCount - 1; i++) {         
       for (var j = 0; j < rowCount - i - 1; j++) {        
            var row1 = rows.item(j);            
            var row2 = rows.item(j + 1);                          
            var mat1 = row1.Itm_no.rawValue || "";             
            var mat2 = row2.Itm_no.rawValue || "";                          
            // Compare and swap if needed             
            if (mat1 > mat2) {                
             // Swap all field values                
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Itm_no");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Pro_desc");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "qty_ucomm");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Guid_pric");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Discount");                 
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Unit_price");   
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Net_amt");       
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "Vat_Rate");     
              swapFieldValues(row1, row2, "VAT_amt");              
              }         }     }         

  function swapFieldValues(row1, row2, fieldName) {         
  var field1 = row1.resolveNode(fieldName);         
  var field2 = row2.resolveNode(fieldName);                  
  if (field1 && field2) {             
  var temp = field1.rawValue;             
  field1.rawValue = field2.rawValue;             
  field2.rawValue = temp;         }    

}

}

) ();

Any inputs/suggestions are appreciated. Thanks!

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA 2025 Release New Functions

entry.title: Re: Adobe Form: Subform in every page
entry.content:
Good day @Dario_Bondoni 

Thank you for your question.

The best practice is to convert header subform into a table header row. Below is the reason.

In summary, due to the clean-core principle in public cloud, the system does not allow you to place data-bound subforms in Master Pages. That is the reasons why you get printing errors while trying to place delivery note fields there.

However, as mentioned above, you can workaround this by placing the header subform inside the same flowed parent as the item table or convert the header into a table header row. Which means your header must be flowed or semi-flowed and not fully positioned. The table header rows will automatically repeat on every page and will work in all overflow scenarios.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

SAP Forms Service by Adobe, Editing the Form Layout Using Adobe LifeCycle Designer

Check out this Blog: How to restrict a logo placed in master page of adobe form to only first page

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom Adobe Form How to Print 7 Outputs with Differe...
entry.content:
Good day @Yash_Rudraksha 

Thank you for your question.

Just to add to the answer you got from @HenrikeGrtecke 

Yes, public cloud allows you to print seven different invoice copies but not by triggering seven printouts. The Output Management in public cloud allows only one print form per invoice.

However, you can achieve your requirement by implementing the logic inside the Adobe Form. You should create a repeated subform that contains the full invoice layout and repeat it seven times. Consider using a small script to assign the correct label for each copy (Original, Duplicate, Triplicate, Extra Copy). The result will be a single PDF containing seven print copies with your desired headers.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

SAP Forms Service by Adobe & Restrictions.

Similar question: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/repeating-multiple-header-rows-of-table-in-subsequent-pages/qaa-p/4750150#M1809258

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Schedule Job for Mass changes to purchase orders
entry.content:
Good day @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question.

Due to the public cloud’s clean-core principle, scheduling recurring mass-change jobs when you use the Mass Changes to Purchase Orders app is not permitted. The app only supports manual, one-time executions.

You can use the Build Process Automation if your business requires recurring PO updates. This will enable you to call the official purchase order OData API (only for fields that API supports). Otherwise, you will have to continue triggering mass-changes manually.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

API for Purchase Order, Configure Automation Capabilities Prerequisites, Configuring the SAP Build Process Automation Integration

You may consider lend your vote to that improvement requirement to further highlight the need. Potentially SAP might consider a solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Story of SAP Materials Management Module in Implementation Projects
entry.content:
SAP MM

 SAP Materials Management is filled with many information from the theoretical part, but going to the practical part in the implementation projects. Here we are having another side from the story. When there is a SAP MM module required in an implementation projects, that doesn't mean that everything in MM module in the theoretical part is required to be implemented, but we just take from the MM module what is required to fulfill the business need. Some implementations could have some cycles from SAP MM as optional, that are not required to be part of the project. It is about adapting the MM module to the business need. Here is a big reason that even after consultants make a end to end cycle they still haven't covered all the MM module aspects. At this point they have covered the basic MM module standards and any new added part due to a specific business need for a client requirement. 

SAP Materials Management is related to all the process for the materials from the start of having a business need triggered by a certain material requirement, that will lead to the procurement decision that will require the SAP MM module to facilitate the full process. Starting that any client who require to procure material need the support of MM module to handle the full process in a smooth and efficient way. This material passes by the full procurement process until they are in the warehouse, where the client have a full control on this material either by consumption, selling them or even sending them to a customer. Materials Management in implementation projects should be implemented in a way that make the business make the full procurement cycle matching their old processes they used to make, just with some advancements and new easier ways of handling and reporting.

SAP Materials Management starts by the normal procure 2 pay process. The business says "We want to buy these materials or services for a specific reasons". They start contacting the procurement department about this requirement. If there is no a planning module that determine the quantity required. They can determine the quantity based on their historical data or just the materials that have been consumed from the warehouses and it is needed to be refilled. Now quantity is determined at this point they need to start creating an internal request to purchase these materials and in MM module it is called the purchase requisition screen. It is a screen that translates this step in the procurement by adding all the required data about the material and assigning a source of supply. This source of supply can be general supplier, fixed supplier and even one time supplier. SAP helps clients to determine the best suppliers through "Request for Quotation -> Quotation -> Price Comparison". These steps help to select the supplier that matches the client needs from the quantity and the value perspective.

Until that point we need to ask one question, where is the data of the material and suppliers are coming. That is why SAP is providing a master data, which means a constant long term source of data that can feed the full transactions to have a successful SAP procurement cycle. Master data should contain all the data regarding the material such as name, description, weight, unit of measure, price control and profit center. The supplier must contain the required data for it's name, address, bank account and roles such as supplier or customer. Feeding SAP with all the required clear data in the master data will ensure a successful accurate SAP MM procure 2 pay cycle. As part of master data SAP is providing some kind of container that is called purchasing info record this container contain both information from the vendor master and the material master. It helps to retrieve data in a smooth way in the procurement process.

Having everything prepared from the material and supplier. Here the time came to send the formal request to the vendor to send the materials to our warehouses. This step is translated in SAP as the purchase order screen. In this screen we add all the details about this purchase of the materials. Most of the data can be imported from the purchase requisition by referencing this purchase order to that purchase requisition. In PO (Purchase Order) client can add the supplier Org. structure (Plant & Storage Location). Also one or multiple materials can be added with all the required pricing conditions, quantity, delivery date, currency and unit of measure. It could be also added as a scheduled materials, where these materials can be delivered on a planned sequential dates like some can come at day 12 other can come at day 20 other can come at day 30. It is like you are dividing the delivery of these materials on multiple days.

This purchase order should contain all the required data as it will be sent to the vendor. Here we are going to another point with a question "Shall the user just create the purchase order, save it and send it directly ?". There should be kind of release strategy, approval strategy, review strategy and even a controlled way over this critical step. That is why SAP provide some kind of workflow that help purchase order to pass by multiple approval levels only the individuals users in every approval level can approve this purchase order. If a purchase order have four approval levels this means that the purchase order is being reviewed four times before it is being released to the vendor. Release strategy is a way of having a confidence that this purchase order is being released in the correct way that matches the business requirements. Same release strategy can be on the purchase requisition and purchase order.

After the vendor receive the purchase order now the vendor is aware with the material that is required to be delivered in quantity, delivery date and it's price. Now the vendor can start sending the materials in a confident clear way to the warehouses of the client. Once the materials are received to the client location. They are not directly placed in the warehouse they should be reviewed for quality and quantity. That is why SAP is providing three stock types: unrestricted stock, quality inspection stock and blocked stock. According to the state of the materials it is placed in this type of stock. SAP is providing a way called transfer posting to be able to transfer these materials on the system level as on ground level. After the materials are inspected and they passed the quality test. They start placing this materials in the warehouse, so same activity should be mapped on the system. Here the goods receipt step comes into the picture. 

Client starts creating a goods receipt with respect to the purchase order. It is translated that if the quantity increased in the warehouses it should increase on the system level. After creating the goods receipt by entering the data from the reference purchase order and adding all the required data of plant and storage location that has received this material. The stock will increase in the system and this will appear in SAP stock reports. SAP understand the stock movements through movement types. Every stock movement has a specific movement type that is translated to an action. Selecting the correct movement type will make the SAP system understand that this delivery caused an increase in the stock. After stock is fully recieved it's time to pay the vendor through the invoice. At this point invoice is created through a screen in SAP referencing the Purchase order and Goods Receipt to ensure the full accuracy which is being called 3-way match. After the invoice is created and verified through the accounting documents. Finance now can pay the vendor for this materials delivery.

In this article we spoke on a MM cycle from the business level and how it is translated to the system level. MM module is a large core module with many dependencies and many criteria. Making one end to end implementation won't make you cover all the SAP MM module parts. It differs according the business need. MM module is a very interesting module because it deals with a part of the business very critical related to the supply chain. Keep exploring the SAP MM module and would be glad if you leave comment on my article.

 SAP Supply Chain Management  MM (Materials Management)

entry.title: Harmonizing tracking across SAP Business Network for Logistics
entry.content:
With SAP Business Network for Logistics release 2511, SAP harmonizes freight execution tracking across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (FC) and SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace (GTT). This article outlines the new, harmonized tracking experience and the role of the shared Web UI for manual event reporting—the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app —which provides a consistent look for role-appropriate views by shippers and carriers, and ties events to a central tracking table accessible from both Freight Collaboration (FC) and Global Track and Trace (GTT).

This unification consolidates information shared across FC, Dock Appointment Scheduling, and GTT. As part of the product roadmap, the legacy apps ‘Track Freight Movement’ for FC shippers and ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ for FC carriers are planned for deprecation in May 2026. GTT solution owners gain an additional reporting channel, enabling data contributors to report events via the Web UI.

Alongside the shared event-reporting application, we refined the tracking scenarios in FC and GTT.

This blog is structured as follows:

  • Introducing the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app
  • Use-case differentiation for event tracking in FC and GTT
  • Next steps for shippers / solution owners
    • FC shippers using basic tracking
    • GTT solution owners receiving tracking information through B2B connectivity with data contributors
    • GTT solution owners planning to request event reporting via Web UI from some data contributors and C shippers wanting to leverage
  • Next steps for carriers / data contributors
    • Carriers using the legacy ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app
    • Carriers or data contributors connecting via API or EDI
    • Carriers newly requested by their shipper customers to report events via the Web UI
  • Where to find more information

 Please note, there is also a dedicated webinar on tracking harmonization scheduled for November 26th. 

Register here

 

Introducing the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app

The ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app has been introduced for both shippers and carriers.

It supports shippers in gaining visibility into shipment execution and in managing freight activities with flexible event intake options, while enabling carriers to report events via Web UI, while still leveraging the existing API or EDI options for automated reporting. The app also allows shippers to report events on behalf of their carrier. All events are displayed in a unified view, independent of the submission channel.

Shippers can view carrier milestones (regardless of how the event was received), report planned and unplanned events, provide estimates or delays, view event history, and access attachments.  This allows all of the stakeholders associated with the shipper to stay informed, when a tracking update is made by the shipper themselves. 

Carriers can report milestones and events (planned or unplanned), provide estimates or delays, and view event history, independent of reporter or channel.  Manual reporting through the new app gives carriers an option, in addition to automated reporting through the existing API and EDI, to report events and stay n sync with shipment execution. 

The following screens illustrate the carrier view.

Figure 1: Main view, filter section and worklist

 Figure 2: Detail view, header and tabs

 

Figure 3: Report planned event from header

 

Figure 4: Report unplanned event

 Figure 5: View event history

 

Figure 6: Detailed event overview

 

This carrier how-to video describes the app in detail.

The shipper view and use of the app differ only in minor aspects; more details are available here.

Shippers currently operating with the ‘Track Freight Movement’ app and carriers operating with the ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app are encouraged to commence adoption of the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app, with ample time to adopt prior to conclusion of the legacy apps in May 2026.

 

Use-case differentiation for event tracking in FC and GTT

As noted earlier, we have introduced a shared application for event reporting, while maintaining the existing API and EDI options for automated reporting. While supporting these options for  tracking data reporting, we can clarify the use-cases and tracking scenarios between FC and GTT.

Going forward, FC will continue to support collaboration between shipper and carrier for contracting, settlement, and dock appointment scheduling. For tracking, FC provides basic milestone event tracking, document attachments, and ETA updates.

GTT supports the same basic tracking as FC, along with more advanced shipment and order-fulfillment tracking scenarios, including geolocation updates, map view, and emissions data, for shipments in the context of the purchase order, sales order, or stock transfer order to which the shipment pertains.  

The graphic below illustrates the differentiation of use cases when using the “Manage Freight Execution” app.

 

In FC, carriers or visibility providers can report milestones and ETAs for road and ocean transports via the web UI or API. Events reported by warehouse or gate operators are included in the ’Manage Freight Execution‘ app. FC shippers can view the events in the event history.

In GTT, data contributors—visibility providers and carriers—can directly report milestones, ETAs, and geolocation updates via API, for shipper’s information and use in the existing ’Track Shipments‘ app. Carriers can now also report events via the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ web UI, sharing specifically milestones, ETAs and documents. Reporting stays in sync between the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ and ‘Track Shipments’ apps.

Synchronization with the S/4HANA remains unchanged for both FC and GTT.

 

Next steps for shippers / solution owners

FC shippers using basic tracking

With this release, we deliver enhanced consistency to improve data reliability and alignment across the landscape. Carriers and shippers can report milestones, ETA, as well as unplanned events via the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app in the web UI, ensuring timely and comprehensive event reporting. In addition, ocean freight tracking is now available, extending visibility to sea shipments and enabling end-to-end tracking.

Please consider the following enablement steps

  1. Notify business users about the new application and update role collections. Admins should either create a new role collection or add the role templates 'ManualReportingDisplayTemplate' and 'ManualReportingProcessTemplate' to an existing role collection. If added to an existing collection, all users in that collection will gain access to the app; if a new collection is created, assign the relevant users to it.

 

Note: SAP will enhance carriers’ role collections on productive carrier tenants. On test tenants, shippers must update their test carriers’ roles.

2. Start using the new 'Manage Freight Execution' application as soon as possible. The legacy application 'Track Freight Movement' remains available until deprecation.

3. Encourage your carriers to adopt and use the new 'Manage Freight Execution' application.

 

GTT solution owners receiving tracking information through B2B connectivity with data contributors

Functional enhancement from this release does not impact their current use case – no changes or next steps required.

 

GTT solution owners planning to request event reporting via Web UI from some data contributors and FC shippers wanting to leveraging advanced tracking

GTT solution owners who want carriers to report events via the web UI can now use the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app. Events submitted through the web UI are visible in the existing  ‘Track Shipments’ app.

Going forward, the map view, geolocation reporting, are no longer available in FC. GTT is SAP’s solution for advanced tracking and order-fulfillment monitoring across sales, purchase, and stock transfer orders, inbound advance ship notices (ASNs), and outbound deliveries. In addition to road and ocean tracking, it supports air and parcel tracking; impact analysis for late or delayed shipments; emissions tracking; and provides a flexible UI and event-to-action scripting for automated alerts and notifications. Further, GTT tracking is not only based on freight order and freight booking level. GTT  can also generate tracking units based on freight orders or freight bookings, based on freight units or containers. GTT is both tightly integrated with SAP S/4HANA and able to be connected to non-SAP applications.

Please consider the following enablement steps (for GTT solution owners only steps 5 and 6):

  1. Subscribe to SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace and onboard.
  2. Decide how you want your freight documents to be tracked in GTTOption 1: Standard IDOC (recommend; Advantage: support advanced tracking, including FU, multiple tracking units (e.g. containers), events reported from S/4, customized events reporting, but requires additional configuration). For more details, see using standard extractor codesOption 2: SOAP message (TransportationOrderGenericTrackedProcessRequest_Out) for TM freight order/booking in GTT (routing request can be entered via customer ticket, component SBN-LBN-INT). Less effort if you are already using this SOAP message for Track Freight Movement app, but limited scope, e.g. only FO and FB with one tracked object (e.g. 1 container per shipment).  
  3. Replicate location from S/4HANA to Location master of BN4L
  4. Maintain system ID and logical system ID in ‘System Connection’ app (see screenshot) 

      5. (Visibility Provider integration – no GTT configuration required, but double check on tracking information in each      shipment e.g. carrier reference, carrier identifier, tracked object, …     

     6. Setup carrier manual reporting via WebUI

  • Invite carriers to onboard via Carrier Onboarding Guide (Note: Please contact your SAP network services lead to guide with aligning the carrier LBN ID and carrier identifier, e.g. SCAC code to leverage Visibility Provider service. Or Maintain Alternate ID in Custom Header of ‘Configure Partner Connection’ app by entering “LBN_CUSTOM_CARRIER_ALT_ID” as Key and “SCAC#1234” as value)
  • Maintain carrier’s LBN ID in business partner master, e.g. update Business' Partner LBN ID in S/4HANA
  • Maintain carrier LBN IDs in carrierListForManageFreightExecution value in Event-to-Action Script in gttft1 model

  • To process events in the same way as in the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app, you must set event status to be triggered by actual technical timestamp in the ‘Manage Models’ app - see Edit the Tracked Process

  •  Adjust entries in ‘Configure Partner Connections’ app e.g, previously maintained “SCAC#1234” should be replaced by the LBN ID - see 'Create Partner Connection’

     7. Get shipper ready to work with ‘Manage Freight Execution app’

  • The admin users need to either create new role collection or add the new roles templates ‘ManualReportingDisplayTemplate’ and ‘ManualReportingProcessTemplate’ to existing role collections. If added to existing role collection, then the users in that role collection will have access to the app. If a new role collection is created, then the users should be added to that role collection.

 

Next steps for carriers / data contributors

Carriers using the legacy Freight Orders for Reporting app

Carriers currently using the ‘Freight Orders for Reporting’ app should start using the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app as soon as possible, leaving ample time for adoption before deprecation in May 2026.

Detailed how-to video for carriers on how to use the app can be found here.

 

Carriers or data contributors connecting via API or EDI

For carriers and data contributors currently reporting via API or EDI, there are no changes.

 

Carriers newly requested by their shipper customers to report events via the Web UI

Carriers without an active account in SAP Business Network for Logistics will receive an invitation from their shipper or solution owner to join the network. A detailed guide to activating the account after receiving an invitation is available here.

Further, shippers or solution owners need to notify their carriers if they want them to report via the new ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app. The carrier’s administrator must assign the necessary roles in the ‘User Management’ app and inform the relevant business users.

A step-by-step tutorial video for carriers on using the ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app is available here.

 

Where to find more information

Below, please find a collection of useful links related to the tracking harmonization enhancements from this release.

 

In addition, I would like to point you to our upcoming webcast on November 26th, 10 am CET where you can hear directly from our experts and ask questions – register here

 

SAP Help Portal – What’s New

Feature detail deck on tracking harmonization

Carrier how-to video on ‘Manage Freight Execution’ app

SAP Business Network Freight Execution L2

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace L2

Getting started with SAP Business Network for Logistics

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The above summarizes tracking harmonization as part of the 2511 release. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2511 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: SAP SD Rebates migration to SAP S4 HANA Settlement Ma...
entry.content:
It is technically possible to migrate closed rebate agreements and settlement documents from ECC to S/4HANA, but it is not supported by standard conversion tools. SAP’s recommended practice is to migrate only open agreements and use archiving/reporting for closed ones. If the client insists, you will need a custom migration approach or specialized data migration tools, since S/4HANA has replaced classic rebate processing with Settlement Management (Condition Contracts)

My recommendations would be

  • If audit access is the only driver → Use archiving/reporting (best practice).
  • If client insists on full migration → Develop a custom conversion program to map ECC rebate agreements into S/4HANA condition contracts, with settlement history stored for reference.
  • Tools: SAP Migration Cockpit can handle billing documents, but rebate agreements/settlements will require custom ETL or ABAP programs.


Below would be some Key Considerations

  • Audit compliance: Ensure migrated data is clearly marked as “historical” so it doesn’t interfere with live rebate processing.
  • Data volume: 10 years of billing + rebates is heavy; performance and storage must be planned.
  • Reconciliation: You’ll need to prove that migrated settlement values match ECC records.
  • Effort vs. benefit: Custom migration adds cost and complexity; weigh against simpler archive/reporting solutions.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic value for @title annotation - is it possible?
entry.content:
Hey, there is no official solution, but I guess it's possible to implement some hacks. Proceed at your own risk.

So as you noted it's not really possible to use other JSONModels.  The source must be a ResourceModel. 

So what you could do is creating a second ResourceModel (to keep the original ResourceModel hack free) (could be named i18nDyn or similar) in the manifest.json and also a new folder (i18nDyn) with properties files in each language (i18nDyn_de.properties etc). It should contain the label keys which you reference in your annotation.

E.g. add an annotation country @title: '{i18nDyn>country}' (uses the new ResourceModel) to your data and add a line country=DUMMY to your i18nDyn.properties file.

Now here comes the ugly part: Replace the DUMMY values with actual dynamic values. To do so implement a lifecycle hook (like onInit) in your controller or Component and add the following code

const bundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel('i18nDyn').getResourceBundle();
// access private properties of bundle. ugly and dangerous!
const properties = bundle.aPropertyFiles[0].mProperties;
// modify the values of the keys
properties.country = "Germany";
// now "country" is not "DUMMY" anymore

 This should then work in p13n dialogs as well as regular tables and filter bars.

entry.title: Re: Query on Replenishment strategy in storage type
entry.content:
When you trigger replenishment, the system creates a replenishment request (essentially a requirement). The request quantity is calculated based on the bin’s stock at that moment (0 → max 200 in your example). If you don’t choose Immediate WT Creation, the request sits in the queue until you later create the WT.

This setting tells the system: when creating the WT, recalculate the required quantity based on current stock in the bin. However, this recalculation only works if the replenishment request is flagged to allow adjustment. In practice, EWM often does not reduce the WT quantity if you’ve already manually changed the bin stock, because the replenishment request is still for 200 units. The system assumes the request is valid and creates a WT to fulfill it.

Having said that why you saw 200 instead of 150 is because, the replenishment request was created for 200 units when the bin was empty. Even though you manually put away 50 units, the request itself was not updated. At WT creation, the system still honored the original request quantity. The “New Quantity at WT Creation” setting doesn’t override the request — it only recalculates if the request type and strategy allow dynamic adjustment.

So check the below areas

In customizing under Activate Replenishment Strategies, check if the strategy allows recalculation at WT creation. Some strategies like planned vs. automatic behave differently.

Verify whether the request is set to be “flexible” or “fixed.” If fixed, the WT will always match the request quantity.

Ensure that the stock check at WT creation is active. In some versions, this requires additional customizing in the replenishment control parameters.

entry.title: Re: Story of SAP Materials Management Module in Implementation Projects
entry.content:
It is a nice story. However somehow biased. You focus mainly on the purchasing process. In my opinion what MM is all about is inventory management, i.e. inventory planning and controlling. In other words making sure we stock what is needed but no more than that. Having said that, in my opinion the heart of MM is inventory controlling and document analysis reports and above all MRP planning and MRP exceptions.

If you focus on purchasing only, you lose all the automation that SAP provides. Purchases need to be plan manually outside of the system and ERP becomes an overpriced cash register - transactions are just registered there while management is still done in spreadsheets.
